section.heading: Argument of Allan A. Ryan, Jr.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You may continue.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. White, I want to make sure that I made myself clear in answering your question earlier.
If the Court should decide, contrary to our submission, that specific intent is an element of voluntariness, it would still, in our view, have to address the other two questions, namely --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Both of them.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Both of them, although as we say in our brief, we would not defend the constitutionality of the presumption in those circumstances.
But the question would still be whether clear and convincing evidence is required of voluntariness, or whether the statute is constitutional.
And we presume the Court would address the presumption, even though we don't defend it.
I think our position is best stated by Chief Justice Warren in his dissent in the Perez case, which as I noted was specifically approved by the Court in Afroyim.

We think that this Court should recognize, as Chief Justice Warren did, and I quote "The principle that conduct of a citizen showing a voluntary transfer of allegiance is an abandonment of citizenship, and thus that any action defined by statute by which the citizen manifests allegiance to a foreign state may be so inconsistent with retention of citizenship as to result in a loss of that status.

"If the conduct described in the statute manifests what Chief Justice Warren called a "dilution of undivided allegiance sufficient to show voluntary abandonment of citizenship," then the Government may give formal recognition to the inevitable consequence of the citizen's own acts without regard to specific intent.
We submit that taking an oath of allegiance to a foreign government is such conduct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, you address that to what particular facet of the issues before us?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: The first issue, Mr. Chief Justice.
The question whether specific intent is a necessary element of an expatriating act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Not to the burden of proof issue?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that -- In our view, that question has to be addressed before the burden of proof issue is addressed.
In our view, that is the touchstone of the Perez dissent and the Court's opinion in Afroyim, one which the Court of Appeals did not follow here.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: As indicated by my question before lunch, what bothers me in this case is the applicability of this statute to this particular case.
This person already was a citizen of Mexico and owed allegiance to Mexico, therefore.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, he did, Mr. Justice Stewart.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: In this particular case, why did his statement of his allegiance to Mexico change the status quo at all?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Under Mexican law, Mexico, like United States, does not favor dual citizenship, and it has this certificate of Mexican nationality which formally recognizes the individual as a citizen of Mexico.
But in the process of doing so, it requires him to surrender his allegiance to any other country, particularly that of which he is also a national.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But before he signed anything, this person, Mr. Terrazas, was a citizen of Mexico, owed allegiance, as such, to Mexico, was also a citizen of the United States, and owed allegiance, as such, to the United States.
And whether either Mexico or the United States individual nationality, he was a citizen of each state, of each country.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And, therefore, why did this signing of an oath of allegiance, or an affirmation of allegiance to Mexico change the status quo at all?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Change the status quo of his dual nationality?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Because he took the oath of allegiance to Mexico.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why did that add anything to what he already owed?
He was a citizen of Mexico.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, as a dual national, his allegiance is in something of a tension.
He owes --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Precisely, but in fact he was, wasn't he?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: In fact, he was a dual national, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Had he ever given an allegiance formally to Mexico?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Not before this act, that I am aware of.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Would he have lost his Mexican citizenship if he had never signed an oath of allegiance?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I don't believe so, Mr. Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Then I share my brother, Stewart's --

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: He testified that he believed that he had to sign this certificate, or this application for Mexican nationality, in order to graduate from the college that he was attending.

Now there is evidence in the record that says that was not so, but regardless of that his testimony was that he believed he could not graduate from the school unless he signed this application for a certificate of Mexican nationality.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How does Chief Justice Warren's adjective "undivided" allegiance bear on this, if it does at all?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It bears on it because by applying for a certificate of Mexican nationality, by swearing his allegiance to Mexico, he demonstrates that he allegiance to the United States is certainly divided, and in fact nonexistent.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Why?
Didn't he already owe allegiance to Mexico if he was a citizen of Mexico?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I assume he did.
As a national of Mexico, I assume he did.
But he, for whatever reason, he thought it was to his advantage to --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And you are not relying at all on his renunciation of United States citizenship in this case?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, as I answered to Mr. Justice Stevens earlier, we are not relying on that as the basis, because the statute, as we describe, I believe, on page 48 of our brief, has four or five specific expatriating acts.
Renunciation of citizenship is one of them, but -- on which we are not relying.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: When you talk about renunciation, do you include with that the election that comes -- that most dual citizens have to make sometime in their lifetime -- and, as I understand, under United States law, as well -- to choose one or the other citizenship?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I wouldn't want to say that I would call that renunciation.
I don't know that I wouldn't.
It would have to depend on the specific act that he did in furtherance of this election.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do the laws of the United States provide that a dual national has to elect at sometime or other during his lifetime, after he reaches 21, to --

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Not to my knowledge, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: He could have gone through his entire life being a citizen of each country?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: As far as I know, yes, sir.
I am not aware of any provision of United States law that says a dual national has to elect at some point with one or the other.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What could Mexico do, for example, about enforcing any obligations of citizenship, except when he was, perhaps, within the boundaries of Mexico?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: As a dual national, there probably was not much that Mexico could do.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What could we do if -- the United States do, for example, about military service, if he was in Mexico?
Would he be in default if he were drafted, for example?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: He was subject to the draft and, in fact, he was given a physical at one point, and was subject to the normal process of the draft.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If that occurred when he was in Mexico and he just didn't respond, he would be in some form of AWOL, wouldn't he?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I assume he would be in some sort of trouble, yes, sir.
He was in Mexico, and, in fact, I think the record shows that he did respond.
He did come up and take his physical, and so forth.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Similarly, I suppose, if he were in the United States and he were a citizen of Mexico, and Mexico had the draft, he would be in default in Mexico.
So his citizenship -- His being a Mexican citizen does involve some obligation, some duties to the country?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I would assume that under Mexican law he does have some obligations to Mexico.
That is one of the reasons that dual nationality is not a particularly favored status in any country.
But in this case, as the Consul told him, there was nothing illegal about it.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Ryan, what is the purpose of the affidavit on page 38 of the Appendix?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: On page 38, that is the affidavit that the Appellee signed before the Consul when he came back with the forms that the Consul had given him to be sent up to the State Department for a final determination of his nationality.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Why don't you rely on that as establishing an intention?
He uses the word "intention" to relinquish United States citizenship.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: He does use that phrase.
There are other statements that he made at the same time, in which he said, "I have no intention of giving up my citizenship."
They are just squarely contradictory.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Was the other statement also sworn to?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It was not sworn, no, sir.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Wasn't that to be resolved by the State Department?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: The State Department did resolve it, although the exact weight that they placed on intention I don't know.
But they resolved that he had lost his citizenship.
And the Court of Appeals has remanded this case to the District Court, because it also has not passed on these conflicting statements of intention.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Was this affidavit executed for the purpose of making clear that he was not subject to draft in the United States?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: No, I would not say that it was done for that purpose.
It was done to forward his --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you can forward papers without swearing you are not a citizen of the United States.
It must have had some purpose.
What was it?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: The purpose, I believe, was to give the State Department a basis to determine whether he had voluntarily committed an expatriating act or not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The purpose was to tell the State Department that he had intentionally relinquished his citizenship in the United States?
That's what it says.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It does say that.
And --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why do you resist?
Yes, why don't you rely on that?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: We don't rely on it in this Court because the Court of Appeals made no finding on that issue when it faced the case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What finding do you need in face of that affidavit?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: There were other statements that were executed at the same time which are squarely contrary.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Were any statements subsequent to this that are to the contrary?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: No, sir, at the same time.
This is the affidavit.

He also answered some questions in a questionnaire, and he also wrote out a letter in his own hand, all of which, the three documents, the affidavit and the questionnaire and the letter, were all sent to the State Department at the same time.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the questionnaire has, as I think you pointed out, conflicting statements.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that's not sworn to, is it?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: The other statements are not sworn to, as far as I know.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: What I don't understand is why this affidavit doesn't settle this case.
If intent is requisite, and if an act may be evidence of intent, it seems to me, at least on the surface -- perhaps I don't understand it -- that you have both here.
He went to Mexico, went to school there, swore in a document that hasn't been repudiated, so far as I know, that it was his intention to relinquish his United States citizenship.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: If this Court should hold that intent is required, it may well be that we will argue in the District Court that there is all the evidence of intent that is needed.

But we have not taken that position here because the Court of Appeals announced this requirement in this case for the first time, and then remanded to the District Court for findings of fact on that issue.

We did not want to come up here and ask this Court to make findings of fact as to whether he did or did not have an intention, when the Court of Appeals has not done so and, in fact, remanded to the District Court for precisely that purpose, stating that credibility was an issue.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Does the State Department have a fact-finding process for determining these things, or do they go directly, de novo, to the District Court?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: The determination is made in the first instance on the papers that are submitted, and then there is an administrative appeal if the individual wants it, in which there is live testimony taken.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Facts were found there, were they not?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, but the trial in the District Court was de novo.
It was not a review of the State Department record.
There is a statutory right to a de novo trial, and that was done here.
I would like to reserve the remainder of my time for rebuttal.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Ditkowsky.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and Members of the Court, may it please the Court.

The issue to be determined, as we understand it, is whether a native-born American citizen can be denaturalized or denuded of his American citizenship by a minimum standard of proof, equal to or less than that of a simple negligence case.
We believe also that Addington v. Texas is espoused under this particular issue.
The Court considered the applicability of the Fourteenth Amendment to the standard of proof in Addington.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When you say "or less than that of a simple negligence case," is that an issue here?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, when you talk about preponderance of the evidence, when the reviewing court looks at preponderance of the evidence, the reviewing court looks to determine if there is one scintilla of evidence that would sustain the verdict of the District Court.
If they find that scintilla of evidence, then they sustain the verdict.
Now, that may or may not have been a preponderance.
That's the reason I use the word "less."

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: In Addington, someone was being incarcerated.
Your client is not being incarcerated.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Our client is worse than being incarcerated.
Our client is losing the right to have rights, the most valued right --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: That is just a lot of kind of rhetoric, isn't it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No, it is not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: He is not forbidden to move any number of places that he wants to the way the person in Addington was who was confined within the walls of an institution.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He is not only confined -- He is confined without the laws of the United States, because not being a citizen he doesn't have the right to American citizenship.
He could very well be barred from entry into the country.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But he can go anywhere else in the world he wants to, can't he?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He was born here, he is a native-born American.
He was born within sight of this Courthouse.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Can't he come in here with a visa?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: But that is still a matter of privilege.
It is not a matter of right, and it takes away the most valued right that the courts have consistently held, from Afroyim, Nishikawa, Perez, you name it.
The courts --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I think you would say this proof has to be beyond a reasonable doubt.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I would like to see proof beyond a reasonable doubt.
I would like to see the most stringent proof required, rather than the standard of clear, convincing and unequivocable.
As pointed out in the Addington case, there were three standards of proof that were determined.
The first standard of proof was the minimum standard, which was preponderance.
This involves cases where society really doesn't have much at stake.
Then you have the cases where society has a great deal at stake, and cases in which the risk of error can't be tolerated.
Those primarily are the criminal cases.
Then you have the middle ground cases, and they are divided into two basic sections.
The first section is the private case, where you have civil fraud and action to declare a child born in wedlock illegitimate, an action to enforce an oral contract to make a bequest.
To these we apply the standard of clear and convincing.
Then we have the more public cases which Addington talked about, the deportation case, the naturalization case, the civil commitment case, and we believe the expatriation case.
Important here --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why would your client sign the affidavit Mr. Justice Powell referred to?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: The reason my client signed the affidavit was he was frightened.
This is a young man --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Is the question of voluntariness in the case?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Yes sir, it certainly is.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He was twenty-two, college educated, fluent in Spanish?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, we have to go back --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you agree with all that?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No.
Our client signed the affidavit -- Our client signed an application for a certificate of Mexican nationality in his home in Niles, Michigan, sometime in 1970.
We've got a number of dates.
Counsel this morning said September 1970.
Mrs. Ibarra testified November 1970.
The court found August 3rd, Mr. Parson said April 3rd.
We don't even know when the event occurred.
In addition to that, the court was presented -- the District Court -- was presented with another application for certificate of Mexican nationality.
This certificate of Mexican nationality did not even bear the Plaintiff's signature.
This had his name spelled wrong, and the name --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes, but the affidavit -- and I go back to it -- was in November of '71.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: When he was a year older.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: "I further swear the act mentioned above was my free and voluntary act, and that no influence, compulsion, force or duress was exerted upon me by any other person, and that it was done with the intention of relinquishing my United States citizenship.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Unfortunately, that is not a true statement of what actually occurred.
This young man came to the Consulate office, after having been at a party.
He was told that he had committed an overt act of treason and he had to go to the Government, the Consulor -- c-o-n-s-u-l rather than c-o-u-n-s-e-l to get a determination of citizenship.
The documents he signed said "registration."
This young man was frightened, his father had died a short while before this, and he put himself in their hands and he signed the documents.
You can see if you look at Exhibit 14A exactly the type of pressure that he was under.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Would you have any case if Perez v. Brownell were the law?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Yes, I think I would.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Under what grounds?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Under the Fourteenth Amendment, and the history of the Fourteenth Amendment cited in Afroyim.
The Fourteenth Amendment --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But Afroyim overruled Perez.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: I am saying if Perez v. Brownell were the law.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I would think so.
I think that even with Perez v. Brownell being the law, we have a different act involved.
We still are involved with the question of standard of proof to be involved.
The standard of proof that's required proves its voluntariness Perez v. Brownell did not abrogate the standard of voluntariness.
So, the first step is to prove voluntariness.
The second step is to prove what, in fact, he did.
And these burdens are on the Government.
In order to prove what anybody did, you have to prove certain things.
One, intent two, what happened, where it happened, who was present.
You've got to prove some kind of foundation.
The record here is totally devoid of any foundation.

And when we look at the Fourteenth Amendment and look at the history of the Fourteenth Amendment, as indicated by the Afroyim case, the intention of the Citizenship Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment was to prevent exactly what has happened in this particular case.
And getting back to Addington again, we have to weigh two things.
What error can we constitutionally allow to occur, and the relative importance of society.
And we submit that the relative importance of society in this particular situation is supreme.
We also point out --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: You would be satisfied with the Addington standard?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, I personally would want beyond a reasonable doubt, but if I had -- it was all I could get -- I would take the Addington standard.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Now, what is the affidavit that you referred to?
Tell me about the setting of the one that you identified as 14A.
In that one, he said -- And it is obviously more in the nature of a letter, not a form of some kind, "I feel more Mexican than American.
I want to stay and live here.
I plan on marrying a Mexican girl.
I've learned what a great country Mexico is.
I feel part of Mexico.
I have many relatives here, I want to be near them.
Even my taste in foods is Mexican.
I could not lead a double life any more.
"Now that last sounds as though he is saying, informally, he doesn't want dual citizenship any more, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, 14A is not reproduced.
Fourteen is reproduced.
Fourteen is the product of 14A.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What is 14A?
Did he write that?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He wrote it under the guidance of the Consular officials.

Fourteen A -- the testimony relative to the 14A was that he prepared a document, and then a Consular official, who happened to be a Mexican national, proceeded to edit that document, taking out many of his statements.
One of the statements was that he had been told by a Consular official that he had committed an overt act, or treasonable act.
This kid was scared to death.
He believed that he had to do specifically what his attorney told him, what his Consul told him.

And on that basis, because of the fiduciary relationship that was imposed on him, or he believed it had occurred, he was misled and led to sign the documents that were not in accord with objective reality.
This should not be sufficient to take away his citizenship.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: This does not read -- at least in my experience -- like something that someone told him to write.
It looks like a candid expressions of a person who is trying to state the facts.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I can only tell you, Your Honor, that 14A has a particular statement, and it does have the statement that he had been told by a Consular official that he had committed an overt treasonable act.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Am I looking at the same thing?
Exhibit 14 at page 10A of Appellant's Appendix.
What are you talking about when you say "14A"?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: 14A is the document that gave rise to Exhibit 14.
Let me explain.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where is 14A in the Appendix?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: 14A is not reproduced in the Appendix.
We were not given the opportunity to add to the Appendix.
The Government came to this Court and said -- and asked this Court --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Where is the document 14A?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: It should be in the record.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: We don't have it here in any of these papers?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: It is not in any of these papers.
The printing of an Appendix was dispensed with upon the Government's motion.

Then the Government proceeded to print an Appendix to their brief, and consequently the documents that we asked to be reproduced and the sections of testimony we asked to be reproduced were not, in fact reproduced.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You can always put them in as an appendix to your brief, can't you?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, when we asked for our brief to be printed, we did have documents attached to that, and they were not printed with them.
I understand they were photocopied and copies of some of those documents were -- The Clerk --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you suggesting that something prevented you from giving what it is you suggest is missing?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, how can I put it?
When I sent in to the Court the Brief for the Appellant, I sent in a document that had exhibits attached to it.
When it was printed, it was printed without adding any of my exhibits.
Among the exhibits that I had attached were statements of Mrs. Ibarra taken at trial, where she admitted the alteration of his document and the editing of his document.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Is that the thing that you sent into the Court, the green thing?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Yes, this is a photocopy of what I sent into the Court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, that certainly doesn't comply with our rules as to size or anything else, does it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, we were granted leave to proceed as a pauper, and we proceeded to send in our brief to the Court and the Court printed our brief.
And what came out was this brief which does comply.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Did you ask that these other items be printed?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, I sent it and then I called the Clerk's office afterwards and I asked the Clerk's office what happened to my exhibits that were attached, and I was told that they were photocopied and copies were given to each of the Justices.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that's what we have here?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: It says "Appendix to Brief for the Appellee."

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I assume that is it, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, can you tell us in this document where 14A is?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No.
I did not reproduce 14A because there is only one copy of 14A, and 14A is something that cannot be entirely reproduced, because what it has in there are many colored pencil marks and scratch marks.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Couldn't it be typed and reproduced in that way?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: You still can't reproduce the colors.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You are relying on 14A for something, aren't you?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Yes, I am relying upon --

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: How does it help us if we don't have it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, I did produce many of the pages that were involved in 14A.
I did not reproduce it, but I did have testimony in connection with it, and I reproduced sections of the testimony where it was discussed, and where Mrs. Ibarra testified as to what she had done.
And we take the position that in her editing his document she showed exactly the power that she had over him, or that the Consular official had over him.
I am sorry I didn't reproduce 14A, but I had no ability to do so, and.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: What is 14A?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: It is the original questionnaire which eventually became 14, Fourteen is produced for the Court by the Appellant.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You say it doesn't exist?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: It exists in the record.
There is only one copy of it.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Where is that?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That is in the record.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Here?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought you said a minute ago it wasn't here.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No, I don't have it in the documents that I produced for the Court, but it is in the actual trial record that was brought into this Court.
There is one concession that is made, which is part of the weighing factor, that goes along with the statement of the Court in Addington.
Addington made a statement that the function of the legal process and the burden of proof, as part of it, was to minimize the risk of an erroneous decision.
On page 16 of Mr. Vance's jurisdictional statement, in a footnote -- I believe Footnote 11 -- Mr. Vance concedes that the burden of proof on a given issue may be dispositive of the issue.
Now, expatriation is a right that is given to an individual citizen.
It is not a right given to the Department of State or Government.
It is a right which must be exercised voluntarily by the citizen.
Voluntary means -- It means voluntary, it doesn't mean equitous.
It doesn't mean res ipse loquitor, like occurred in this case.
It does not mean punishment for a crime.
If I am the worst person in the world, that's no right to take away my citizenship.
Punish me for the crime, but don't take away my citizenship.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Do you concede that it can be an act voluntarily done, inconsistent with allegiance to the country, without necessarily also having the intent, specific intent, to renounce citizenship?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: If there is no intent to do the act, it can't be voluntary.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But if there is intent to do the act, but not the intent to specifically renounce citizenship.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: You can't make that broad a statement.
If Congress should declare that wearing a red shirt should be an act of expatriation, the red shirt has no relationship to citizenship.
Consequently, I can wear a red shirt until the sun sets in the east and still I will not do an act which I should be expatriated for.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What about enlisting in the Army of a foreign country?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, it depends on the circumstances.
In Nishikawa where there is coercion, absolutely not.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What about where there is no coercion?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Where there is no coercion?
We have allowed Americans to enlist in the Army of Israel and we have not expatriated them.
We have --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What was the expatriation in Perez v. Brownell?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That was voting.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Was there a finding there that it was done with the conscious intent to relinquish citizenship?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I think it is implicit in the Court's decision, and I think that they did feel that that was such an act that it did have a conscious intent, because the fact that when you vote in a foreign election -- If I were to vote in the election in Mexico, for instance, I would be involved in the intimate process of Government in Mexico, and that is pretty good evidence of being an interloper or of --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But if you enlist in the Mexican Army, you may be ordered to invade the United States.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, that is a problem that does exist, and then comes the question of coercion.
That's the reason this area of voluntariness is so very important.
That's the reason we really have to determine as to -- and on a case by case basis -- what the act was, why it was done, where it was done, how it was done, and who was present.
It cannot be a secret type of situation.
It cannot be a situation that only I know what I have done, only you and I know what I have done.
It must be some formal act.
The statute itself does say "formal."

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: When you have dual citizenship, there is a great difference between giving up one there, isn't there?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Yes.

When you have dual citizenship -- When I have dual citizenship, I have a vested right in both my American citizenship and in my other citizenship, and only I should have the right to give it up as an individual and as a member --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Couldn't you do something there, that if you just had one citizenship you wouldn't have any trouble.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's right.
If I had just one citizenship, that's true.
Where I have dual citizenship, --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You had that problem.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I haven't made any change in my statute.
Mr. Terrazas did not change his situation.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Why did he file that affidavit?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: The only explanation for it is stupidity, or the indication by the Consular official that this was the right thing to do.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In reading the parts that I just read to you, does that sound like something dictated by someone else, or does it sound like a person who sits down and writes out his thoughts?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, as one lawyer to another, what we have in many situations is, the lawyer suggests sometimes the manner in which one is going to present a particular fact situation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Including his statement that not only did he like the people and had a lot of relatives, but that he even liked Mexican food better than ours.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That is still not expatriation.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We are probing for intent.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: These things sound quite sincere.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: They may sound sincere, but they are not necessarily intent of giving up one's citizenship.
I like Swedish cooking.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He almost has dual citizenship.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He does have dual citizenship.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's not a theory that you pull down out of the clear blue, is it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I am sorry?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You don't pull down, quote, "dual citizenship," end quote, out of the clear blue sky.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean something when you say that.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And so he meant something when he said it.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Certainly.
He --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: He meant that he was giving up the dual citizenship.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He did not intend to give up his dual citizenship.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I thought you said he did.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No, he did not intend to give up his citizenship.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Oh, he didn't mean what he said?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He said what he said in those statements because it was suggested to him that that was the thing to say, that was what the Department of State wanted to hear.
So he said it.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Including the statement, "I could not lead a double life any more.
There comes a time in everyone's life when he has to sit down and decide what he wants to do with his life.
I did this and decided my future happiness was here in Mexico.
For that reason, I became a Mexican."

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I believe so, because he was told that he had committed an overt act of treason against the United States Government.
He would never be allowed to go home.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What was the nature of the act?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: The act?
We don't know what the act was.
It may very well have been a third person's act.
There is no evidence in the record that the forged application for citizen of Mexican nationality did not promulgate the certificate of Mexican nationality.

When Mr. Terrazas appeared at the Consulate in Monterey, Mexico, and he told Mr. Parsons that he had in his possession his certificate of Mexican nationality, Mr. Parsons said to him, "That's it, you are no longer an American citizen.
You have committed an expatriating act.
We have to document your case.
I can't make that determination.
"And when Parsons was asked about it, what did he say?
He said, "Mr. Terrazas was surprised and Mr. Terrazas did not know that he had expatriated himself."
How can an act be voluntary if you don't know what you have done?

And, again, getting to this burden of proof issue, we still have the situation that even in the most simple case if I want to prove that I have spoken before the Supreme Court, I must still be able to have somebody testify what was done, when it was done, where it was done, who was present, and in a case like this, I have to prove scienter.
When dealing with something as important as expatriation, we are entitled to know with specificity.
The Government said we took an oath of allegiance.
Mexico does not have an oath of allegiance.
Mexico has no oath whatsoever.
This is admitted by Parsons.
It is admitted by the Government.
Consequently, we couldn't even take an oath.
We are accused of taking a bite out of the apple, and then in the reply brief we are accused of taking a bite out of an orange.
The two are distinct situations.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He went to school down in Mexico?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He went to school down there.
Many Americans have gone to school down in Mexico.
Then he went to medical school down in Mexico.
In fact, it used to be recommended that that was a place to get a degree.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Was the application he signed an application for a certificate of Mexican nationality, in 1970?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: It was a document that was signed in blank.
It did not contain the words that my brother said it did.
It did not contain the specific renunciation of.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Had he applied for a certificate of Mexican nationality or not?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He signed a document which his father sent -- His Uncle George was a Mexican official and that blossomed somehow into a certificate of Mexican nationality.
The document is not rationally distinguishable from the document signed by Mrs. Byrnes in the Matheson case, which occurred essentially --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Did somebody issue him a certificate of Mexican nationality?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: The Mexican Government issued a certificate of Mexican nationality.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: What did that certificate have in it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That evidenced his Mexican citizenship, which he had already.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And what else did it evidence?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: In my opinion, that is all --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, it says that he has expressly renounced all rights and adherence to other nationalities.
That's what that certificate says.
And so that was an official certificate, wasn't it?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: There is no question about it.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And he had applied for such an official certificate, hadn't he?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, that --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Had he or hadn't he?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: He signed a document blank and a document with a forged signature --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: At least the Government thought he had applied for it, the Mexican Government.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: The Mexican Government did, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And I suppose that if the application hadn't had in it this renunciation, he never would have gotten the certificate.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I don't know, Mrs. Byrnes did.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: The certificate recites that he has made this renunciation.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: The certificate does say that, but we do not know how that certificate was obtained.
No evidence was proven as to how this --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did he ever make any effort to send it back when he saw that it contained a renunciation?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No, he did not send it back.
He didn't even think about it.
He had the document which got him his grades from school and that's all he was interested in.
This was the sole crux of what, in fact, he was interested in.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Mr. Ditkowsky, you said that you didn't know, and none of us knew, what brought all this about.
Could it have been that they found out that he was in Mexico posing as a Mexican citizen?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Are you sure that's not true?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Yes.
He went to school down there.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is there anything in the record that proves that?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: There is nothing in the record that proves --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But you said his uncle was a big Mexican official.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's right, his uncle was a Mexican official.
His mother lives here --

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Could that be the great treason they are talking about?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I don't know where they got the idea of treason.
I don't know where they got the res ips loquitor approach to this matter.
We are asking this Court to declare that statute unconstitutional, require voluntariness and require specifically that the Government prove what happened, how it happened, who was present --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you raise any question about the constitutionality of the provision that taking an oath of allegiance to a foreign power shall be an expatriating act, in view of the fact that I understand your position to be that one can be a citizen of more than one country at a time?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I believe that statute is unconstitutional because I don't think it has any relationship at all to --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It doesn't necessarily follow that if your basic position is right that you must prove specific intent to relinquish citizenship, that the basic underlying statute is unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: The basic underlying statute does not have to be unconstitutional to sustain my position.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It seems to me that it follows logically, if we should adopt your position, because one can be a citizen of two countries.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And if you must prove specific intent to renounce and so forth, and if you fail to prove that the mere taking an oath of allegiance to another country should not be the constitutionally permissible basis for revoking citizenship.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I think it does follow and I think the Court.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Particularly for a person who is a citizen already.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you wouldn't suggest that these to cases are the same, would you?
You go and you apply for a certificate of Mexican citizenship.
In the one case, you sign a piece of paper that says, "I swear allegiance to Mexico."
Say the other fellow signs a piece of paper that says "I swear allegiance to Mexico and I renounce my allegiance to the United States."
Now, in the second case, there certainly is an intent that is connected with swearing allegiance to Mexico that isn't present in the first?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: Well, except for the fact that our --

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, you wouldn't say the two cases are the same, would you?

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: They are not identical, but our court and our State Department has said that in order to renounce you've got to do it in a particular manner so that that intent is clearly made possible.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But you wouldn't be relying on the renunciation as a separate matter, but you would be relying on a renunciation in order to inform you as to what the intent was in connection with the swearing of allegiance.

turn.speaker: kenneth_k_ditkowsky
turn.label: Mr. Kenneth K. Ditkowsky
turn.text: I want to point out that there was no oath in this case because there was no oath possible.
We are asking this Court to once and for all end this case.
It has gone far enough.
We have fought since 1971 to the present time.
We are asking this Court at the very least to declare Laurence Terrazas a citizen of the United States.
Thank you.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Allan A. Ryan, Jr.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I would like to clear up the status of this Exhibit 14A.
But before I do that, I would like to be very frank with this Court as to the precise problem that the United States sees in the Court of Appeals decision.
That decision, as I stated, requires that the United States prove, by clear and convincing evidence, a specific intent to surrender citizenship.
It is the combination of those two requirements that creates the dilemma to which I referred earlier.

Should this Court hold, as we believe it should, that specific intent is not an element of expatriation and that expatriation can arise regardless of specific intent, if the citizen performs voluntarily a statutorily designated act that demonstrates a transfer of allegiance, then in all candor, I must state that the clear and convincing standard applied to proving the commission of the act of expatriation itself is not an intolerable burden.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Ryan, under prior cases, is it any of the Government's business to say what -- when and under what circumstances a citizen loses his citizenship?
I thought that was the business of the citizen to give up his citizenship.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It is the business of both, because the Government has a legitimate interest in knowing who is a citizen and who is not.
It cannot depend on the subjective intent of --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I thought, arguably at least, on the prior cases, a citizen doesn't give up his citizenship against his will.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: The Government cannot strip his citizenship away from him.
That is Afroyim.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Unless he actually knows that -- at the minimum, he actually knows that some act that he is performing is -- Well, unless he intends to give up his citizenship.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: That is not, respectfully, what Afroyim holds in our view, and we ask the Court not to hold that now.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You haven't gotten much help out of the Court of Appeals, have you?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: No.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: As a matter of fact, Courts of Appeals all read Afroyim that way, against you.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: The Second Circuit and this Seventh Circuit both have.
The Ninth and the Fifth Circuit look the other way, we think, although it is not a square holding.
We discuss those cases in our brief.
It is the standard of proof here applied in conjunction with the specific intent requirement that creates the tough problem.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why wouldn't you say that Afroyim was just wrong?
Here the United States said voting in a foreign election is an act which the Government says amounts to a renunciation of your citizenship.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: We don't believe Afroyim is wrong and we are not asking this Court to cut back --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then why should you be able to say that swearing allegiance to a foreign government is a renunciation of your citizenship?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Because, unlike voting in a foreign election, swearing allegiance to another government, especially when that is done in the context of renouncing United States citizenship, is an act that --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But that isn't your argument.
You don't even make that argument, apparently, that swearing allegiance in connection with renunciation makes it stronger than if you just swore allegiance.
That isn't the way you cast your argument, is it?
Certainly not in your brief.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we said that circumstance would be taken into account.
But even if it is ignored, we think that swearing allegiance to a foreign government is an act intrinsically different from simply voting in a foreign election.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You are saying that's what the Government says that act should mean.
I thought Afroyim, at least arguably, says that we really have to have some proof of what the man subjectively intended by this act, not what some government says.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It is Chief Justice Warren, sir, that I read that statement as coming from.
In his statement --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Chief Justice Warren was in dissent.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: He was, but that dissent later became the basis for Afroyim.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it didn't, because that wasn't the issue in Afroyim, was it?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Afroyim was voting in a foreign election.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It was the same case as Perez, but Chief Justice Warren, in his dissent in Perez, said that there is a difference between voting in a foreign election and naturalizing one's self in a foreign state.
That was the particular example he used.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You still say that if in Afroyim there were two people and one of them had voted and one of them had sworn allegiance, the two cases would have come out differently.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Would have come out differently, yes, sir.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Even though the one who swore allegiance was already a citizen of that government?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Under the circumstances of this case, yes.
The individual there --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: How can it be that if you are already a citizen of Mexico that a certificate stating that you are a citizen of Mexico changes the status?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Because under Mexican law there are certain things that can be done only by a person holding a certificate of Mexican nationality.
It is an official solemn document that you are a full-fledged citizen of Mexico.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: He already was.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: No, he was a dual national.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: He was a full-fledged citizen.
I don't know what a half-fledged citizen is.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It is my understanding that there are certain things that a dual national cannot do in Mexico, even though he -- half of his legal nationality is Mexican.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: There are things nobody can do in Mexico legally.
To what are you referring?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I am referring to certain acts -- and I don't have them specifically at hand, but there is testimony in the record, in the documents, that the Mexican Government requires that those who are born dual nationals have a certificate of Mexican nationality in order to carry out certain things.
For example.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: Well, that's just a matter of proof of what was already a fact, concededly in this case.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, and so he proceeded to be in his interest to take out the certificate of Mexican nationality.

turn.speaker: lewis_f_powell_jr
turn.label: Justice Lewis F. Powell, Jr.
turn.text: To prove what was already a fact, i.e., that he was a citizen of Mexico, and also a citizen of the United States.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: It, apparently, was not sufficiently a fact to the Mexican government.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: My only question is how in this case, at least, can it be considered to be inconsistent with American citizenship to simply preserve the status quo?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Because he was not preserving the status quo.
He was pledging his whole obedience --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Mr. Ryan, why don't you use the argument you have already used in part, that because in this case he not only swore allegiance, but the same as said, "And furthermore I intend by this swearing of allegiance to renounce my citizenship."

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the reason you don't is, as my Brother White has already said, you haven't relied on that throughout --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: He does now.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I can make -- I will tell you precisely what my position is on that argument.
The statute says renouncing United States citizenship before a United States officer, that is an expatriating act.
That is not what happened in this case, and so the Government does not rely on the statute that says --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: No, but I asked you -- There are two parts to this document, one, an oath of allegiance, and second, renunciation language.
Would it be the same legal issue here if we left out the second half of the document and you said yes.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I say yes right now.

The only significance that that renunciation has in the context of this case is that it is a piece of evidence which the State Department and the courts could consider along with all the other evidence in the case, to determine just what happened here.
It is not as we say in our brief, we are not suggesting that the renunciation is an independent legal basis, because it doesn't fit the statute.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: You are saying that, but why isn't the case different if you've got the two together, than if you had just the swearing of allegiance?

For instance, the man swears his allegiance -- assume in this case he had sworn his allegiance and then in parenthesis he said, "And furthermore, I intend by this swearing of allegiance to give up my citizenship in the United States," close parenthesis.
And then the question is What did you intend by your swearing of allegiance?
Isn't that a different case than if he just swears allegiance?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: That may make it a stronger case for expatriation, but it does not change the legal basis on which the expatriation occurs, which is the swearing of allegiance, not the renunciation of Mexican citizenship.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: You hope that's the rule.
What if we need an intent?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we are saying that intent is not needed.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know you do, but what if you lose on that?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: If we lose on that, then --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why don't you say that intent is here?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: As I said before lunch, if we lose on that issue we may well go back to the District Court and say the intent is here.

But the fact is that the Court of Appeals made no finding on that issue, and we did not think it proper to come up and argue to this Court that it should make a finding, which is in fact what I believe the Appellee is doing, asking this Court to rewrite the record and --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The finding to be made would be in the District Court in the first instance, perhaps is What is the significance of the statement of renunciation of American citizenship, and how does that bear on the first half of that point?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, that is evidence of his intent to surrender his American citizenship.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Strong evidence, I suppose you would say?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: I would certainly argue that in the District Court, if it comes to that, yes, sir, whether it is ultimately persuasive or not.
It is not the only statement of intent.
There are contrary statements, and that is a matter for the District Judge to make findings on in the first instance.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: With the Court's leave, I could explain the situation of Exhibit 14, although my time has expired.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: About 14?
It is available to us now, is it not?

turn.speaker: allan_a_ryan
turn.label: Mr. Allan A. Ryan, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice, it is.
It is in the Clerk's office of the Court.
The original exhibits are there.
What happened is, 14 and 14A are both copies of a preprinted form called The Questionnaire, designed to find out what happened in an allegedly expatriating act.
The Vice Consul, in this case, when he first met the Appellee said, "Here, take this questionnaire back home and fill it out and bring it back to us."
The Appellee did so.
He came back and he filled it out. Unfortunately, although not unreasonably, he proceeded on the answering the questions as if he had been naturalized as a Mexican citizen, which in fact he was not.
He was a Mexican citizen by birth.
The Consular officer, the Consular assistant, Maria Ibarra, testified and this is all in the record.
There is no Svengali influence here that she sat down with Mr. Terrazas and she went through question by question.
She said, "Actually, you are not a naturalized citizen, you are a native-born citizen, so this question shouldn't be answered."
She went through page by page while he was there.
He never said anything in response.
He just took her instructions as to the proper way of filling out the form.
She said, "Fine, now that you understand it, please take this fresh form home and complete it with the correct questions answered", which he did.
None of this business about, "I feel more Mexican than American," and so forth, was ever dictated in any way, shape or form by anyone in the Consul.
The record simply doesn't support that.
The question of treason.
There is absolutely no evidence in the record that anyone told him that he was committing a treasonous act.
In fact, the Vice Consul flatly and repeatedly denied that he had ever said any such thing.
The only place that ever shows up is in various statements outside the record, or outside the trial testimony that the Appellee has made.
I would be distressed if this Court were to characterize the record as my opponent has characterized it, because I think those facts are simply not in the record.
The record is a four-volume transcript, and a number of documents which we believe are self-explanatory.
This Appellee was not forced or coerced or hounded by any employee.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I think we have your point now, Mr. Ryan.
Thank you, Gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
